elements.content: Differentiation of xylene isomers remains as one of the most important challenges in the chemical industry, mainly due to the similar molecular sizes and boiling points of the three xylene isomers. Fluorescence-based chemical sensors have attracted wide attention due to their high sensitivity and versatile applications. Here, we report a novel fluorescent metal–organic framework named NUS-40, which is able to selectively detect and discriminate o-xylene from other xylene isomers. Suspension of NUS-40 in o-xylene produces a distinct red shift in the fluorescence emission compared to that in either m-xylene or p-xylene. Moreover, the extent of peak shift is dependent on the concentration of o-xylene in xylene isomer mixtures, and the observed linear correlation between fluorescence intensity and o-xylene concentration is beneficial for quantitative detection. The possible mechanism of such responsive fluorescence behavior was investigated by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, proton nuclear magnetic resonance, and vapor sorption experiments. In addition, facile metalation of the porphyrin centers with metal ions provides an additional route to fine-tune the sensing properties.
elements.clean_text: Differentiation of xylene isomers remains as one of the most important challenges in the chemical industry, mainly due to the similar molecular sizes and boiling points of the three xylene isomers. Fluorescence-based chemical sensors have attracted wide attention due to their high sensitivity and versatile applications. Here, we report a novel fluorescent metal-organic framework named NUS-40, which is able to selectively detect and discriminate o-xylene from other xylene isomers. Suspension of NUS-40 in o-xylene produces a distinct red shift in the fluorescence emission compared to that in either m-xylene or p-xylene. Moreover, the extent of peak shift is dependent on the concentration of o-xylene in xylene isomer mixtures, and the observed linear correlation between fluorescence intensity and o-xylene concentration is beneficial for quantitative detection. The possible mechanism of such responsive fluorescence behavior was investigated by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, proton nuclear magnetic resonance, and vapor sorption experiments. In addition, facile metalation of the porphyrin centers with metal ions provides an additional route to fine-tune the sensing properties.

elements.content: Luminescent porphyrin-based MOF material NUS-40 and its isostructural analogue NUS-40-Zn were designed and synthesized for chemical sensing. The proper pore sizes and conjugated systems make them excellent candidates for fluorescence-based selective detection of o-xylene from other xylene isomers.
elements.clean_text: Luminescent porphyrin-based MOF material NUS-40 and its isostructural analogue NUS-40-Zn were designed and synthesized for chemical sensing. The proper pore sizes and conjugated systems make them excellent candidates for fluorescence-based selective detection of o-xylene from other xylene isomers.

elements.content: Xylene is an important petrochemical commodity and can serve as the intermediate for many valuable products such as phthalic anhydride, terephthalic acid, and isophthalic acid. However, the similar physicochemical properties of the three xylene isomers (o-, m-, and p-xylene) make it difficult to distinguish one from another. At present, separation and quantification of xylene for workplace safety purposes rely on gas chromatography coupled with flame ionization detection (GC-FID) or mass spectrometry (GC-MS). While highly accurate, it is desired to replace these bulky analytical instruments with portable devices which can enable rapid and convenient on-site measurements. Fluorescence-based sensing technologies are promising alternatives due to the fast electron and energy transfer in these processes, affording quick response and high accuracy in the according molecular sensors. Some fluorescent materials have been evaluated for xylene sensing. For example, Tang’s group reported TPE-β-CD nanosheets exhibiting sensitive detection toward p-xylene. Our group reported ultrathin two-dimensional porous organic nanosheets named NUS-24 with size-selective turn-on fluorescence properties toward xylene isomers. Despite the progress, precise design is still required for a more effective discrimination of the xylene isomers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Xylene is an important petrochemical commodity and can serve as the intermediate for many valuable products such as phthalic anhydride, terephthalic acid, and isophthalic acid. However, the similar physicochemical properties of the three xylene isomers (o-, m-, and p-xylene) make it difficult to distinguish one from another. At present, separation and quantification of xylene for workplace safety purposes rely on gas chromatography coupled with flame ionization detection (GC-FID) or mass spectrometry (GC-MS). While highly accurate, it is desired to replace these bulky analytical instruments with portable devices which can enable rapid and convenient on-site measurements. Fluorescence-based sensing technologies are promising alternatives due to the fast electron and energy transfer in these processes, affording quick response and high accuracy in the according molecular sensors. Some fluorescent materials have been evaluated for xylene sensing. For example, Tang's group reported TPE-β-CD nanosheets exhibiting sensitive detection toward p-xylene. Our group reported ultrathin two-dimensional porous organic nanosheets named NUS-24 with size-selective turn-on fluorescence properties toward xylene isomers. Despite the progress, precise design is still required for a more effective discrimination of the xylene isomers.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of hybrid porous materials constructed by coordination bonding between organic linkers and metal nodes. Several MOFs have been developed, possessing good performance for adsorptive separation of xylene isomers. For example, El Osta and coworkers utilized MIL-53­(Fe) for the chromatographic separation of xylene isomers. Long’s group employed multiple metal site interactions in Co2(dobdc) and Co2(m-dobdc) to accomplish the same goal. Ghosh and coworkers reported a Zn-based flexible MOF for selective p-xylene sorption. Nevertheless, most of these studies focus on the separation of xylene isomers, while the discrimination and detection of xylene isomers remain more or less unexplored. The ease of modifying the physicochemical properties of MOFs by judiciously selecting the constituent organic linkers and metal secondary building units (SBUs) has allowed the rational design of luminescent MOFs for chemical sensing. In a prominent example, Kitagawa and coworkers prepared 1,4,5,8-naphthalenediimide (NDI)-embedded MOFs which can distinguish different phenyl ring substituents of aromatic volatile organic compounds (VOCs) by their corresponding fluorescence spectra. Although this study indicates the feasibility of designing fluorescent MOFs for the discrimination of xylene isomers, similar properties have been rarely reported in other fluorescent MOFs due to the numerous factors involved in the fluorescence process.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a class of hybrid porous materials constructed by coordination bonding between organic linkers and metal nodes. Several MOFs have been developed, possessing good performance for adsorptive separation of xylene isomers. For example, El Osta and coworkers utilized MIL-53(Fe) for the chromatographic separation of xylene isomers. Long's group employed multiple metal site interactions in Co2(dobdc) and Co2(m-dobdc) to accomplish the same goal. Ghosh and coworkers reported a Zn-based flexible MOF for selective p-xylene sorption. Nevertheless, most of these studies focus on the separation of xylene isomers, while the discrimination and detection of xylene isomers remain more or less unexplored. The ease of modifying the physicochemical properties of MOFs by judiciously selecting the constituent organic linkers and metal secondary building units (SBUs) has allowed the rational design of luminescent MOFs for chemical sensing. In a prominent example, Kitagawa and coworkers prepared 1,4,5,8-naphthalenediimide (NDI)-embedded MOFs which can distinguish different phenyl ring substituents of aromatic volatile organic compounds (VOCs) by their corresponding fluorescence spectra. Although this study indicates the feasibility of designing fluorescent MOFs for the discrimination of xylene isomers, similar properties have been rarely reported in other fluorescent MOFs due to the numerous factors involved in the fluorescence process.

elements.content: Porphyrin-based MOFs (PMOF) constitute a group of important luminescent MOFs with outstanding light-harvesting capabilities, molecular sensing properties, and emissions in the visible region. The high level of conjugation in porphine (comprising 18 π-electrons in a planar, continuous macrocycle) ensures strong absorption in the visible region, which is an essential prerequisite for fluorescent detection. However, most reported PMOFs exhibit large pore sizes and cage cavities, limiting their applicability toward small molecule detection. For this purpose, we hypothesize that microporous PMOFs would combine the inherent light-harvesting capability of the porphyrin macrocycles with conformational selectivity for certain small molecules, which may lead to optimal sensing performance in differentiating xylene isomers.
elements.clean_text: Porphyrin-based MOFs (PMOF) constitute a group of important luminescent MOFs with outstanding light-harvesting capabilities, molecular sensing properties, and emissions in the visible region. The high level of conjugation in porphine (comprising 18 π-electrons in a planar, continuous macrocycle) ensures strong absorption in the visible region, which is an essential prerequisite for fluorescent detection. However, most reported PMOFs exhibit large pore sizes and cage cavities, limiting their applicability toward small molecule detection. For this purpose, we hypothesize that microporous PMOFs would combine the inherent light-harvesting capability of the porphyrin macrocycles with conformational selectivity for certain small molecules, which may lead to optimal sensing performance in differentiating xylene isomers.

elements.content: Herein, a novel PMOF (NUS-40) based on rare-earth (RE) metal chain SBUs was synthesized, exhibiting highly fluorescence-based sensitivity in differentiating o-xylene from xylene isomers. The flexible coordination modes of RE clusters enable the condensation of one-dimensional (1D) RE metal oxide chains, resulting in a highly stable microporous structure of NUS-40 with optimal pore dimensions for xylene detection. Linear variation of the fluorescence intensity of NUS-40 was observed across a wide range of o-xylene concentration, which can be advantageous for quantitative detection applications. Furthermore, we performed metalation on the porphyrin rings with zinc ions to obtain NUS-40-Zn, which exhibits increased o-xylene/m-xylene selectivity. The promising sensing performance demonstrated in this work paves a way for the rational design of porous fluorescent materials for precise molecular discrimination.
elements.clean_text: Herein, a novel PMOF (NUS-40) based on rare-earth (RE) metal chain SBUs was synthesized, exhibiting highly fluorescence-based sensitivity in differentiating o-xylene from xylene isomers. The flexible coordination modes of RE clusters enable the condensation of one-dimensional (1D) RE metal oxide chains, resulting in a highly stable microporous structure of NUS-40 with optimal pore dimensions for xylene detection. Linear variation of the fluorescence intensity of NUS-40 was observed across a wide range of o-xylene concentration, which can be advantageous for quantitative detection applications. Furthermore, we performed metalation on the porphyrin rings with zinc ions to obtain NUS-40-Zn, which exhibits increased o-xylene/m-xylene selectivity. The promising sensing performance demonstrated in this work paves a way for the rational design of porous fluorescent materials for precise molecular discrimination.

elements.content: All the chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Rigaku MiniFlex 600 powder X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed using a Shimadzu DTG-60AH instrument. The samples were heated from 50 to 800 °C under an air flow at a rate of 5 °C min–1. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained using a Kratos AXIS Ultra XPS system (Kratos Analytical Ltd.) with a monochromatic Al Kα radiation source (1486.6 eV) at 15 kV. The solid-state UV–vis spectra were detected by a SHIMADZU UV-2450 spectrophotometer in the range of 400–800 nm using BaSO4 as the standard. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained by a Bio-Rad FTS-3500 ARX FTIR spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Rigaku MiniFlex 600 powder X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed using a Shimadzu DTG-60AH instrument. The samples were heated from 50 to 800 °C under an air flow at a rate of 5 °C min-1. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained using a Kratos AXIS Ultra XPS system (Kratos Analytical Ltd.) with a monochromatic Al Kα radiation source (1486.6 eV) at 15 kV. The solid-state UV-vis spectra were detected by a SHIMADZU UV-2450 spectrophotometer in the range of 400-800 nm using BaSO4 as the standard. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained by a Bio-Rad FTS-3500 ARX FTIR spectrometer.

elements.content: Y­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.08 mmol, 30 mg), tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (H2TCPP, 0.004 mmol, 3 mg), DMF (2 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), and formic acid (300 μL) were combined in a 20 mL vial and heated at 120 °C for 48 h. Purple single-crystals were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and dried at room temperature. The phase purity of the as-synthesized product was confirmed by comparing the experimental and simulated X-ray diffraction patterns (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Solvothermal Synthesis of NUS-40

Y(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.08 mmol, 30 mg), tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (H2TCPP, 0.004 mmol, 3 mg), DMF (2 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), and formic acid (300 μL) were combined in a 20 mL vial and heated at 120 °C for 48 h. Purple single-crystals were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and dried at room temperature. The phase purity of the as-synthesized product was confirmed by comparing the experimental and simulated X-ray diffraction patterns (Figure S1).

elements.content: The reaction mixture of the single-crystal synthesis was scaled fourfold, maintaining the same molar composition in 20 mL scintillation vials. The reaction time was extended to 60 h under the same reaction temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Scaled-Up Synthesis of NUS-40

The reaction mixture of the single-crystal synthesis was scaled fourfold, maintaining the same molar composition in 20 mL scintillation vials. The reaction time was extended to 60 h under the same reaction temperature.

elements.content: NUS-40 (50 mg) were added to 10 mL of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O/ethanol solution (20 mg mL–1), and the mixture was stirred under room temperature for 48 h, yielding wine-colored crystals. The isostructural nature of the product was confirmed by comparing the experimental and NUS-40 PXRD patterns (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of NUS-40-Zn

NUS-40 (50 mg) were added to 10 mL of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O/ethanol solution (20 mg mL-1), and the mixture was stirred under room temperature for 48 h, yielding wine-colored crystals. The isostructural nature of the product was confirmed by comparing the experimental and NUS-40 PXRD patterns (Figure S1).

elements.content: A Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer was used to collect the crystallographic data. The temperature was maintained at 100 K. Graphite-monochromated Cu Kα (λ = 1.54184 Å) was used for the radiation source. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using SHELXTL version 5.1. All the metal atoms were located first, followed by oxygen and carbon atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the ligand were placed geometrically. Thermal parameters were refined anisotropically for all nonhydrogen atoms. The crystallographic data were combined with thermogravimetric analysis information to derive the final formula of NUS-40 as C106H73Y3N11O22. The detailed crystallographic data are listed in Table S1. Crystallographic data of NUS-40 (1838778) were deposited into Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Topology information on NUS-40 was calculated by TOPOS 4.0.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Crystallography

A Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer was used to collect the crystallographic data. The temperature was maintained at 100 K. Graphite-monochromated Cu Kα (λ = 1.54184 Å) was used for the radiation source. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 using SHELXTL version 5.1. All the metal atoms were located first, followed by oxygen and carbon atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the ligand were placed geometrically. Thermal parameters were refined anisotropically for all nonhydrogen atoms. The crystallographic data were combined with thermogravimetric analysis information to derive the final formula of NUS-40 as C106H73Y3N11O22. The detailed crystallographic data are listed in Table S1. Crystallographic data of NUS-40 (1838778) were deposited into Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Topology information on NUS-40 was calculated by TOPOS 4.0.

elements.content: N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K were collected on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. The guest molecules trapped within the frameworks of NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn were exchanged with fresh absolute ethanol daily for 3 days before activation under vacuum (100 °C for 10 h) prior to the sorption tests.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Measurements

N2 sorption isotherms at 77 K were collected on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. The guest molecules trapped within the frameworks of NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn were exchanged with fresh absolute ethanol daily for 3 days before activation under vacuum (100 °C for 10 h) prior to the sorption tests.

elements.content: Vapor phase adsorptions at 293 K of o-, m-, and p-xylene by NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn were measured at low vapor pressure ranges (P/P 0 = 0.05–0.5) using a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ3. Between each sorption test, solvent exchange with methanol was performed for three days with daily replacement of fresh solvent. The activation took place under vacuum at 100 °C for 10 h to completely remove the guest molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Xylene Isomer Vapor Adsorption Measurements

Vapor phase adsorptions at 293 K of o-, m-, and p-xylene by NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn were measured at low vapor pressure ranges (P/P 0 = 0.05-0.5) using a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ3. Between each sorption test, solvent exchange with methanol was performed for three days with daily replacement of fresh solvent. The activation took place under vacuum at 100 °C for 10 h to completely remove the guest molecules.

elements.content: The experiments were performed by soaking finely grounded MOFs (ca. 1 mg) in 3 mL of pure or mixed solutions of xylene isomers, followed by photoluminescence tests. Before each fluorescence test, the mixtures were sonicated for 5 min under room temperature to obtain uniform suspensions. All the tests were carried out on a PTI QuantaMaster 800 spectrofluorometer at room temperature with an excitation wavelength of 420 nm and an emission slit width of 10 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence-Based Chemical Sensing Tests of Xylene Isomers

The experiments were performed by soaking finely grounded MOFs (ca. 1 mg) in 3 mL of pure or mixed solutions of xylene isomers, followed by photoluminescence tests. Before each fluorescence test, the mixtures were sonicated for 5 min under room temperature to obtain uniform suspensions. All the tests were carried out on a PTI QuantaMaster 800 spectrofluorometer at room temperature with an excitation wavelength of 420 nm and an emission slit width of 10 nm.

elements.content: Time-resolved spectroscopic measurements were performed to examine the change before and after the sensing experiments. First, NUS-40 or NUS-40-Zn was tested in the MeOH solution by fluorescence lifetime measurements using a laser light source with the excitation at 450 nm. Then, different xylene isomers were added into the solution, and the measurements were recorded under the same conditions. Quantum yields of NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn before and after the sensing experiments were also measured using methanol as the reference with an excitation wavelength of 420 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Lifetime and Quantum Yield Measurements

Time-resolved spectroscopic measurements were performed to examine the change before and after the sensing experiments. First, NUS-40 or NUS-40-Zn was tested in the MeOH solution by fluorescence lifetime measurements using a laser light source with the excitation at 450 nm. Then, different xylene isomers were added into the solution, and the measurements were recorded under the same conditions. Quantum yields of NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn before and after the sensing experiments were also measured using methanol as the reference with an excitation wavelength of 420 nm.

elements.content: First, the MOFs were introduced into mixture solutions containing xylene and methanol (MeOH) of various compositions under shaking for 1 day. The MOF powders were then separated, washed with fresh MeOH twice, and dried. Next, approximately 5 mg of MOF powder adsorbed with xylene was added into an NMR tube and digested with 5 μL of concentrated hydrochloric acid, followed by the addition of 0.5 mL of d 6-DMSO with brief agitation. Finally, the 1H NMR measurements were performed using an Agilent 600 MHz NMR.
elements.clean_text:
1H NMR Measurements

First, the MOFs were introduced into mixture solutions containing xylene and methanol (MeOH) of various compositions under shaking for 1 day. The MOF powders were then separated, washed with fresh MeOH twice, and dried. Next, approximately 5 mg of MOF powder adsorbed with xylene was added into an NMR tube and digested with 5 μL of concentrated hydrochloric acid, followed by the addition of 0.5 mL of d 6-DMSO with brief agitation. Finally, the 1H NMR measurements were performed using an Agilent 600 MHz NMR.

elements.content: The solvothermal reaction of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis (4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (H2TCPP) with Y­(NO3)3·6H2O at 120 °C yielded block-shaped purple crystals of NUS-40 in 82% yield. The molecular formula was determined to be Y3O6(TCPP)2(DMF)2(H2O)­(COO)·DMF.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure and Characterization of NUS-40

The solvothermal reaction of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis (4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (H2TCPP) with Y(NO3)3⋅6H2O at 120 °C yielded block-shaped purple crystals of NUS-40 in 82% yield. The molecular formula was determined to be Y3O6(TCPP)2(DMF)2(H2O)(COO)⋅DMF.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that NUS-40 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with the spacegroup of P1̅ (Table S1). Typically, an asymmetric unit of NUS-40 is constructed by three interconnected Y atoms, two H2TCPP ligands, two coordinated DMF molecules and one coordinated water molecule, one terminal formic acid molecule, and one uncombined DMF molecule (Figure S2). It is worth mentioning that the framework of NUS-40 consists of rare earth metal chains linked by the square planar H2TCPP ligands, which is rare in the reported porphyrin-based MOFs. Trinuclear Y­(III) clusters are bridged by the H2TCPP ligands to form 1D metal chains, which are further linked by the H2TCPP ligands to fabricate the 3D framework (a). In this representation, the organic ligand H2TCPP exists as 3,4-connected and 4-connected nodes within the framework, whereas the trinuclear Y­(III) cluster serves as a 9-connected node with a polyhedral architecture (b). The structure of NUS-40 can be reduced to a (3,4,4,9)-connected network with a Schläfli symbol of {43.52.6} {45.5} {48.57.612.76.83} {52.6}, representing a new topology. In this structure, there exist three kinds of 1D channels with the diameters of 6.1 × 16.8 Å, 7.0 × 17.7 Å, and 7.8 × 17.2 Å considering the van der Waals radii (Figure S3). The total solvent-accessible volume calculated by PLATON is 3366.7 Å3 per unit cell, which is approximately 51.7% of the cell volume. To characterize the potential for guest molecule adsorption, N2 sorption experiments of activated NUS-40 were carried out at 77 K (a), revealing a reversible type-I isotherm with calculated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas of 450 and 663 m2 g–1, respectively. The pore size distributions of NUS-40 calculated using a nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method indicate dominant microporosity at 6 Å, matching well with the crystal structure. In addition, as shown in the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) results, the framework can be maintained up to 400 °C, indicating the excellent thermal stability of NUS-40 (Figure S5).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that NUS-40 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system with the spacegroup of P1̅ (Table S1). Typically, an asymmetric unit of NUS-40 is constructed by three interconnected Y atoms, two H2TCPP ligands, two coordinated DMF molecules and one coordinated water molecule, one terminal formic acid molecule, and one uncombined DMF molecule (Figure S2). It is worth mentioning that the framework of NUS-40 consists of rare earth metal chains linked by the square planar H2TCPP ligands, which is rare in the reported porphyrin-based MOFs. Trinuclear Y(III) clusters are bridged by the H2TCPP ligands to form 1D metal chains, which are further linked by the H2TCPP ligands to fabricate the 3D framework (a). In this representation, the organic ligand H2TCPP exists as 3,4-connected and 4-connected nodes within the framework, whereas the trinuclear Y(III) cluster serves as a 9-connected node with a polyhedral architecture (b). The structure of NUS-40 can be reduced to a (3,4,4,9)-connected network with a Schläfli symbol of {43.52.6} {45.5} {48.57.612.76.83} {52.6}, representing a new topology. In this structure, there exist three kinds of 1D channels with the diameters of 6.1 × 16.8 Å, 7.0 × 17.7 Å, and 7.8 × 17.2 Å considering the van der Waals radii (Figure S3). The total solvent-accessible volume calculated by PLATON is 3366.7 Å3 per unit cell, which is approximately 51.7% of the cell volume. To characterize the potential for guest molecule adsorption, N2 sorption experiments of activated NUS-40 were carried out at 77 K (a), revealing a reversible type-I isotherm with calculated Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas of 450 and 663 m2 g-1, respectively. The pore size distributions of NUS-40 calculated using a nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method indicate dominant microporosity at 6 Å, matching well with the crystal structure. In addition, as shown in the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) results, the framework can be maintained up to 400 °C, indicating the excellent thermal stability of NUS-40 (Figure S5).

elements.content: Single-crystal structure analysis of NUS-40: (a) topology simplification of square shaped ligands and rare-earth metal chains; (b) schematics showing the new topology of NUS-40; (c) the porous structure diagram of NUS-40 along (011) direction.
elements.clean_text: 1  Single-crystal structure analysis of NUS-40: (a) topology simplification of square shaped ligands and rare-earth metal chains; (b) schematics showing the new topology of NUS-40; (c) the porous structure diagram of NUS-40 along (011) direction.

elements.content: (a) N2 sorption isotherms and (b) NLDFT pore size distribution of NUS-40.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) N2 sorption isotherms and (b) NLDFT pore size distribution of NUS-40.

elements.content: Titration experiments were performed in MeOH solutions, and the intensity of fluorescence spectra increased with the addition of different xylene isomers, indicating potential interactions with the framework (). Moreover, after the addition of 120, 120, and 150 μL of o-xylene, m-xylene and p-xylene, respectively, the fluorescence intensity of solutions reached saturation state, likely due to the saturation of sorption. To observe the detection selectivity, we compared and calculated the intensity of fluorescence enhancement after adding equivalent amounts of xylene isomers (120 μL). As shown in d, NUS-40 exhibits a specific detection of o-xylene among the three xylene isomers.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence-Based Detection of Xylene Isomers

Titration experiments were performed in MeOH solutions, and the intensity of fluorescence spectra increased with the addition of different xylene isomers, indicating potential interactions with the framework (). Moreover, after the addition of 120, 120, and 150 μL of o-xylene, m-xylene and p-xylene, respectively, the fluorescence intensity of solutions reached saturation state, likely due to the saturation of sorption. To observe the detection selectivity, we compared and calculated the intensity of fluorescence enhancement after adding equivalent amounts of xylene isomers (120 μL). As shown in d, NUS-40 exhibits a specific detection of o-xylene among the three xylene isomers.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 versus o-xylene (OX) addition in o-xylene/MeOH mixtures; (b) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 versus m-xylene (MX) addition in m-xylene/MeOH mixtures; (c) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 versus p-xylene (PX) addition in p-xylene/MeOH mixtures (λex = 420 nm, c = 0.3 mg mL–1); (d) relative intensity of fluorescence emission after adding 120 μL of different xylene isomers in MeOH solutions.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 versus o-xylene (OX) addition in o-xylene/MeOH mixtures; (b) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 versus m-xylene (MX) addition in m-xylene/MeOH mixtures; (c) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 versus p-xylene (PX) addition in p-xylene/MeOH mixtures (λex = 420 nm, c = 0.3 mg mL-1); (d) relative intensity of fluorescence emission after adding 120 μL of different xylene isomers in MeOH solutions.

elements.content: To further confirm the specific detection properties of NUS-40, the fluorescent spectra were compared among single-component xylene isomer solutions. As shown in a, the strong emission spectra of m- and p-xylene suspensions are located at 658 nm (λex = 420), exhibiting an obvious blue shift of 16 nm compared to that of o-xylene (674 nm), which may be ascribed to the different interactions between the xylene isomers and NUS-40. In addition, the cycling stability is another important indicator for the applicability of sensors. Therefore, the cycling performance of NUS-40 in o-xylene solution was also investigated under the same conditions. Each time, the sample was centrifuged from xylene solution, washed with fresh MeOH, and activated under vacuum at 120 °C. As shown in b, the relative intensity of spectrum could be maintained beyond 99% after 5 cycles, indicating the high stability of NUS-40 after recycling.
elements.clean_text: To further confirm the specific detection properties of NUS-40, the fluorescent spectra were compared among single-component xylene isomer solutions. As shown in a, the strong emission spectra of m- and p-xylene suspensions are located at 658 nm (λex = 420), exhibiting an obvious blue shift of 16 nm compared to that of o-xylene (674 nm), which may be ascribed to the different interactions between the xylene isomers and NUS-40. In addition, the cycling stability is another important indicator for the applicability of sensors. Therefore, the cycling performance of NUS-40 in o-xylene solution was also investigated under the same conditions. Each time, the sample was centrifuged from xylene solution, washed with fresh MeOH, and activated under vacuum at 120 °C. As shown in b, the relative intensity of spectrum could be maintained beyond 99% after 5 cycles, indicating the high stability of NUS-40 after recycling.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 suspended in various xylene isomers at 298 K; (b) relative intensity of NUS-40 suspended in o-xylene solution in cycling stability test (674 nm); (c) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 suspended in various o-xylene and m-xylene mixture solutions at 298 K; (d) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 suspended in various o-xylene and p-xylene mixture solutions at 298 K (λex = 420 nm, c = 0.3 mg mL–1).
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 suspended in various xylene isomers at 298 K; (b) relative intensity of NUS-40 suspended in o-xylene solution in cycling stability test (674 nm); (c) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 suspended in various o-xylene and m-xylene mixture solutions at 298 K; (d) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40 suspended in various o-xylene and p-xylene mixture solutions at 298 K (λex = 420 nm, c = 0.3 mg mL-1).

elements.content: As mentioned before, NUS-40 possesses specific detection for o-xylene in single-component xylene solutions. Nevertheless, multicomponent discrimination is the true deciding factor for industrial chemical sensing applications. To verify the specific detection performance of NUS-40, we suspended the grounded NUS-40 powder in multicomponent xylene isomer mixtures with different ratios and conducted fluorescence tests of the suspensions. Interestingly, the maximum emission peaks of m-/o-xylene mixture solutions locate at 663, 666, and 670 nm with the different m-xylene versus o-xylene volume ratios of 2:1, 1:1, and 1:2, respectively (c). The relationship between the volume percentage of o-xylene and the peak position can be fitted by a linear algebraic equation with R 2 > 0.99 (Figure S8 and Table S2). A similar linear relationship was observed in o-/p-xylene mixture solutions (d and Table S2). In principle, the difference in emission peak location of o-xylene should enable discernment of the o-isomer in the three-component system, which may have more practical relevance. Future work includes the evaluation of xylene discrimination by rare-earth PMOFs in three-component mixtures. The above observations unambiguously demonstrate the interesting property of NUS-40 in differentiating o-xylene from multicomponent xylene isomer mixtures.
elements.clean_text: As mentioned before, NUS-40 possesses specific detection for o-xylene in single-component xylene solutions. Nevertheless, multicomponent discrimination is the true deciding factor for industrial chemical sensing applications. To verify the specific detection performance of NUS-40, we suspended the grounded NUS-40 powder in multicomponent xylene isomer mixtures with different ratios and conducted fluorescence tests of the suspensions. Interestingly, the maximum emission peaks of m-/o-xylene mixture solutions locate at 663, 666, and 670 nm with the different m-xylene versus o-xylene volume ratios of 2:1, 1:1, and 1:2, respectively (c). The relationship between the volume percentage of o-xylene and the peak position can be fitted by a linear algebraic equation with R 2 > 0.99 (Figure S8 and Table S2). A similar linear relationship was observed in o-/p-xylene mixture solutions (d and Table S2). In principle, the difference in emission peak location of o-xylene should enable discernment of the o-isomer in the three-component system, which may have more practical relevance. Future work includes the evaluation of xylene discrimination by rare-earth PMOFs in three-component mixtures. The above observations unambiguously demonstrate the interesting property of NUS-40 in differentiating o-xylene from multicomponent xylene isomer mixtures.

elements.content: Based on the structural analysis, the framework of NUS-40 possesses pore sizes mainly at 6 Å, which are suitable for the trapping of xylene isomers (kinetic diameters of OX, MX, and PX are 6.8, 6.8, and 5.8 Å, respectively). To check the xylene sorption ability of NUS-40, a low-pressure static vapor sorption experiment was performed on activated NUS-40 with xylene vapors at 293 K (a). The o-/m-/p-xylene vapor uptakes of NUS-40 reach 26.7, 16.0, and 20.0 cm3 g–1 (ca. 1.19, 0.71, and 0.89 mmol g–1), respectively, at vapor pressures of ca. 0.25 Torr. Therefore, it can be concluded that NUS-40 shows significantly higher uptake for o-xylene among the three xylene isomers, which can also be confirmed by FTIR. As shown in b, NUS-40 saturated with o-xylene (denoted as NUS-40⊃OX) possesses an additional band at 746 cm–1, which can be ascribed to the C–H stretch vibration in the methyl group of o-xylene. In contrast, the signals of m-xylene and p-xylene cannot be clearly observed in NUS-40 saturated with m-xylene (denoted as NUS-40⊃MX) and p-xylene (denoted as NUS-40⊃PX), respectively (Figure S10). 1H NMR results suggest that two o-xylene molecules can be trapped in one single pore of NUS-40 (c), compared to 1.6 m-xylene molecules and 1.8 p-xylene molecules (Figure S11), respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism Study

Based on the structural analysis, the framework of NUS-40 possesses pore sizes mainly at 6 Å, which are suitable for the trapping of xylene isomers (kinetic diameters of OX, MX, and PX are 6.8, 6.8, and 5.8 Å, respectively). To check the xylene sorption ability of NUS-40, a low-pressure static vapor sorption experiment was performed on activated NUS-40 with xylene vapors at 293 K (a). The o-/m-/p-xylene vapor uptakes of NUS-40 reach 26.7, 16.0, and 20.0 cm3 g-1 (ca. 1.19, 0.71, and 0.89 mmol g-1), respectively, at vapor pressures of ca. 0.25 Torr. Therefore, it can be concluded that NUS-40 shows significantly higher uptake for o-xylene among the three xylene isomers, which can also be confirmed by FTIR. As shown in b, NUS-40 saturated with o-xylene (denoted as NUS-40⊃OX) possesses an additional band at 746 cm-1, which can be ascribed to the C-H stretch vibration in the methyl group of o-xylene. In contrast, the signals of m-xylene and p-xylene cannot be clearly observed in NUS-40 saturated with m-xylene (denoted as NUS-40⊃MX) and p-xylene (denoted as NUS-40⊃PX), respectively (Figure S10). 1H NMR results suggest that two o-xylene molecules can be trapped in one single pore of NUS-40 (c), compared to 1.6 m-xylene molecules and 1.8 p-xylene molecules (Figure S11), respectively.

elements.content: (a) Xylene vapor sorption isotherms of NUS-40 at 293 K under low vapor pressures (0.01–0.5 mbar); (b) FTIR spectra of o-xylene, NUS-40, and NUS-40⊃OX; (c) 1H NMR spectra of NUS-40 after liquid phase adsorption of o-xylene in MeOH solution; (d–f) Structural fragments of NUS-40 with o-xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene, respectively, as determined through molecular force field based calculations of structure optimization. The interactions of each xylene isomer with the pyrrole and benzene rings of NUS-40 as well as the atomic distances are indicated.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Xylene vapor sorption isotherms of NUS-40 at 293 K under low vapor pressures (0.01-0.5 mbar); (b) FTIR spectra of o-xylene, NUS-40, and NUS-40⊃OX; (c) 1H NMR spectra of NUS-40 after liquid phase adsorption of o-xylene in MeOH solution; (d-f) Structural fragments of NUS-40 with o-xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene, respectively, as determined through molecular force field based calculations of structure optimization. The interactions of each xylene isomer with the pyrrole and benzene rings of NUS-40 as well as the atomic distances are indicated.

elements.content: The distinct adsorption capacity may be due to different noncovalent bond interactions of xylene isomers with the framework of NUS-40. To investigate this point, molecular force-field-based calculations were performed on structural fragments of NUS-40 incorporated with isomeric xylene guests using the universal force field as implemented in Gaussian 09. As can been seen in d, the distance between xylene isomers and organic conjugated system enables three possible C–H···π and π···π interaction forces between o-xylene and the pyrrole and benzene rings of NUS-40. In contrast, there are only two kinds of C–H···π interaction forces in the case of m-xylene or p-xylene. As a result, the interaction forces between o-xylene and NUS-40 should be stronger than that of the other two xylene isomers, leading to different energies transferred between xylene isomers and the framework of NUS-40 and accordingly the selective differentiation of o-xylene.
elements.clean_text: The distinct adsorption capacity may be due to different noncovalent bond interactions of xylene isomers with the framework of NUS-40. To investigate this point, molecular force-field-based calculations were performed on structural fragments of NUS-40 incorporated with isomeric xylene guests using the universal force field as implemented in Gaussian 09. As can been seen in d, the distance between xylene isomers and organic conjugated system enables three possible C-H⋅⋅⋅π and π⋅⋅⋅π interaction forces between o-xylene and the pyrrole and benzene rings of NUS-40. In contrast, there are only two kinds of C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction forces in the case of m-xylene or p-xylene. As a result, the interaction forces between o-xylene and NUS-40 should be stronger than that of the other two xylene isomers, leading to different energies transferred between xylene isomers and the framework of NUS-40 and accordingly the selective differentiation of o-xylene.

elements.content: Metalloporphyrins have widespread applications in catalysis and chemical sensing. The introduction of metal ions into the porphyrin center is an effective way to modify the electronic properties of the luminescent materials and in turn their sensing behaviors. In particular, zinc-based metalloporphyrins are often considered as good candidates for luminescence-based chemical sensing. Accordingly, we employed Zn metal insertion to fine-tune the sensing behavior of NUS-40. After soaking NUS-40 in the ethanol solution of Zn­(NO3)2 with stirring at room temperature for two days, the metalated NUS-40-Zn was obtained without loss of the original framework integrity, which was confirmed by the PXRD patterns (Figure S1). Moreover, a shift of N signals and the appearance of new Zn signals at 1022.3 and 1045.5 eV in the XPS spectrum of NUS-40-Zn strongly support the successful introduction of Zn ions into NUS-40.
elements.clean_text:
Development of Metalloporphyrin-Based MOF Sensor

Metalloporphyrins have widespread applications in catalysis and chemical sensing. The introduction of metal ions into the porphyrin center is an effective way to modify the electronic properties of the luminescent materials and in turn their sensing behaviors. In particular, zinc-based metalloporphyrins are often considered as good candidates for luminescence-based chemical sensing. Accordingly, we employed Zn metal insertion to fine-tune the sensing behavior of NUS-40. After soaking NUS-40 in the ethanol solution of Zn(NO3)2 with stirring at room temperature for two days, the metalated NUS-40-Zn was obtained without loss of the original framework integrity, which was confirmed by the PXRD patterns (Figure S1). Moreover, a shift of N signals and the appearance of new Zn signals at 1022.3 and 1045.5 eV in the XPS spectrum of NUS-40-Zn strongly support the successful introduction of Zn ions into NUS-40.

elements.content: The fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40-Zn in xylene isomer solutions are shown in Figure S13. The insertion of Zn ions into the porphyrin centers results in a shift in the energy levels of the material. Closer matching of the energy levels between the analyte and emissive components could increase the efficiency of the energy transfer. Remarkably, NUS-40-Zn shows an improvement in o-xylene/m-xylene sensing selectivity, which is advantageous for the discrimination of these two isomers. The ratio of the degree of fluorescent enhancement between o-xylene and m-xylene [E o‑xylene/E m‑xylene, where E = (I – I 0)/I 0] for NUS-40-Zn is 2.76, compared to 2.39 for nonmetalated NUS-40 (Figures S14 and S18). The change in selectivity may be due to a slightly altered pore environment after zinc incorporation, resulting in different binding interactions with the xylene isomers. Meanwhile, the o-xylene/p-xylene sensing selectivity remains at a similar level after metalation. Similar to NUS-40, NUS-40-Zn possesses specificity for o-xylene and a linear peak shift based on o-xylene concentration in the multicomponent tests (c and d). Hence, the results indicate that metalation of the porphyrin center is a highly effective strategy in fine-tuning the luminescence of PMOFs to meet specific application demands.
elements.clean_text: The fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40-Zn in xylene isomer solutions are shown in Figure S13. The insertion of Zn ions into the porphyrin centers results in a shift in the energy levels of the material. Closer matching of the energy levels between the analyte and emissive components could increase the efficiency of the energy transfer. Remarkably, NUS-40-Zn shows an improvement in o-xylene/m-xylene sensing selectivity, which is advantageous for the discrimination of these two isomers. The ratio of the degree of fluorescent enhancement between o-xylene and m-xylene [E  o-xylene/E  m-xylene, where E = (I - I 0)/I 0] for NUS-40-Zn is 2.76, compared to 2.39 for nonmetalated NUS-40 (Figures S14 and S18). The change in selectivity may be due to a slightly altered pore environment after zinc incorporation, resulting in different binding interactions with the xylene isomers. Meanwhile, the o-xylene/p-xylene sensing selectivity remains at a similar level after metalation. Similar to NUS-40, NUS-40-Zn possesses specificity for o-xylene and a linear peak shift based on o-xylene concentration in the multicomponent tests (c and d). Hence, the results indicate that metalation of the porphyrin center is a highly effective strategy in fine-tuning the luminescence of PMOFs to meet specific application demands.

elements.content: (a) Detailed XPS spectra of the N 1s region in NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn; (b) detailed XPS spectra of the Zn 2p region in NUS-40-Zn; (c) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40-Zn suspended in various o-xylene and m-xylene mixture solutions at 298 K; (d) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40-Zn suspended in various o-xylene and p-xylene mixture solutions at 298 K (λex = 420 nm, c = 0.3 mg mL–1).
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Detailed XPS spectra of the N 1s region in NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn; (b) detailed XPS spectra of the Zn 2p region in NUS-40-Zn; (c) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40-Zn suspended in various o-xylene and m-xylene mixture solutions at 298 K; (d) fluorescence emission spectra of NUS-40-Zn suspended in various o-xylene and p-xylene mixture solutions at 298 K (λex = 420 nm, c = 0.3 mg mL-1).

elements.content: In summary, we designed and synthesized a novel porphyrin-based MOF named NUS-40 containing rare-earth metal chain SBUs and a new topology. Its isostructural analogue NUS-40-Zn was also obtained by metallating NUS-40 with zinc ions. Both NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn exhibit high thermal stabilities, largely because of the rare-earth metal chain SBUs. The proper pore sizes of the framework structures and conjugated systems offered by porphyrin ligands make them excellent candidates for fluorescence-based selective detection of o-xylene among xylene isomers. The increase in o-xylene concentration within bicomponent xylene isomer systems is accompanied by a quantifiable characteristic peak shift, enabling the exact determination of the isomeric composition by fluorescence. These results suggest that fluorescent MOFs with judiciously designed structures (such as NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn demonstrated in this study) can be used for the rapid detection of o-xylene from xylene isomers, paving the way for quick o-xylene monitoring in industrial xylene purification.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we designed and synthesized a novel porphyrin-based MOF named NUS-40 containing rare-earth metal chain SBUs and a new topology. Its isostructural analogue NUS-40-Zn was also obtained by metallating NUS-40 with zinc ions. Both NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn exhibit high thermal stabilities, largely because of the rare-earth metal chain SBUs. The proper pore sizes of the framework structures and conjugated systems offered by porphyrin ligands make them excellent candidates for fluorescence-based selective detection of o-xylene among xylene isomers. The increase in o-xylene concentration within bicomponent xylene isomer systems is accompanied by a quantifiable characteristic peak shift, enabling the exact determination of the isomeric composition by fluorescence. These results suggest that fluorescent MOFs with judiciously designed structures (such as NUS-40 and NUS-40-Zn demonstrated in this study) can be used for the rapid detection of o-xylene from xylene isomers, paving the way for quick o-xylene monitoring in industrial xylene purification.

cln_elements.content:
Y­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.08 mmol, 30 mg), tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (H2TCPP, 0.004 mmol, 3 mg), DMF (2 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), and formic acid (300 μL) were combined in a 20 mL vial and heated at 120 °C for 48 h. Purple single-crystals were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and dried at room temperature. The phase purity of the as-synthesized product was confirmed by comparing the experimental and simulated X-ray diffraction patterns (Figure S1).

Synthesis of NUS-40-Zn

NUS-40 (50 mg) were added to 10 mL of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O/ethanol solution (20 mg mL–1), and the mixture was stirred under room temperature for 48 h, yielding wine-colored crystals. The isostructural nature of the product was confirmed by comparing the experimental and NUS-40 PXRD patterns (Figure S1).

Results and DiscussionStructure and Characterization of NUS-40

The solvothermal reaction of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis (4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (H2TCPP) with Y­(NO3)3·6H2O at 120 °C yielded block-shaped purple crystals of NUS-40 in 82% yield. The molecular formula was determined to be Y3O6(TCPP)2(DMF)2(H2O)­(COO)·DMF.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Solvothermal Synthesis of NUS-40

Y(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.08 mmol, 30 mg), tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (H2TCPP, 0.004 mmol, 3 mg), DMF (2 mL), H2O (0.5 mL), and formic acid (300 μL) were combined in a 20 mL vial and heated at 120 °C for 48 h. Purple single-crystals were collected, washed with fresh DMF, and dried at room temperature. The phase purity of the as-synthesized product was confirmed by comparing the experimental and simulated X-ray diffraction patterns (Figure S1).

Synthesis of NUS-40-Zn

NUS-40 (50 mg) were added to 10 mL of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O/ethanol solution (20 mg mL-1), and the mixture was stirred under room temperature for 48 h, yielding wine-colored crystals. The isostructural nature of the product was confirmed by comparing the experimental and NUS-40 PXRD patterns (Figure S1).

Results and Discussion

Structure and Characterization of NUS-40

The solvothermal reaction of 5,10,15,20-tetrakis (4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin (H2TCPP) with Y(NO3)3⋅6H2O at 120 °C yielded block-shaped purple crystals of NUS-40 in 82% yield. The molecular formula was determined to be Y3O6(TCPP)2(DMF)2(H2O)(COO)⋅DMF.

metadata.title:
Luminescent Metal–Organic Frameworks for the
Detection and Discrimination of o‑Xylene from
Xylene Isomers
